'Alcohol by volume' (abbreviated as 'ABV', 'abv', or 'alc/vol') is a standard
measure of how much alcohol (ethanol) is contained in an alcoholic beverage
(expressed as a percentage of total volume). {{cite web
|url=http://www.lafayettebrewingco.com/beer101.html |title=Lafayette Brewing Co.
|publisher=www.lafayettebrewingco.com |accessdate=2012-02-04 |last= |first=
}} {{cite web |url=http://www.celtic-whisky.com/glossary.htm
|title=Glossary of whisky and distillation |publisher=www.celtic-whisky.com |accessdate=2012-02-
04 |last= |first= }} {{cite web |url=http://www.englishalesbrewery.com/british-brewing-
glossary.htm |title=English Ales Brewery Monterey British Brewing Glossary
|publisher=www.englishalesbrewery.com |accessdate=2012-02-04 |last= |first=
}} The 'ABV' standard is used worldwide.

In some countries, alcohol by volume is referred to as 'degrees Gay-Lussac'
(after the French chemist Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac). {{cite web
|url=http://chemistry.about.com/od/famouschemists/p/gaylussacbio.htm
|title=Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac (1778â1850) |publisher=chemistry.about.com |accessdate=2008-07-
05 |last= |first= }}
